docs.snippet: LEAD: Trade ministers from three continents reported today that they had failed to resolve disputes that are threatening to scuttle efforts to change the global trading system.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Trade ministers from three continents reported today that they had failed to resolve disputes that are threatening to scuttle efforts to change the global trading system.

headline.main: Trade Ministers Fail To Resolve Key Issues

docs.snippet: LEAD: Twenty-two resplendent yachts, ready for racing after a three-and-a-half week layover in balmy Florida, set off for England today in the last leg of the Whitbred Round the World Race.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Twenty-two resplendent yachts, ready for racing after a three-and-a-half week layover in balmy Florida, set off for England today in the last leg of the Whitbred Round the World Race.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: The final push in the Whitbread Round the World Race, a 3,800-mile leg from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Southampton, England, began Saturday with considerable pressure on the leading crew to sail a careful race.

headline.main: Playing It Safely In Whitbread Race

docs.snippet: LEAD: The international drive to reform the world's trading system will fail unless industrial nations agree to scrap their barriers to textile imports from developing countries, the head of the O.E.C.D. said today.      Jean-Claude Paye, Secretary

docs.snippet: LEAD: Anthony G. Barbieri, a former security officer and attache for the State Department, died on Thursday at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

docs.snippet: LEAD: The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, told Congress today that despite recent moves by the Japanese to open their markets, the animosity toward Japan in this country had become ''a tidal wave and you have to run very fast to...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, told Congress today that despite recent moves by the Japanese to open their markets, the animosity toward Japan in this country had become ''a tidal wave and you have to run very fast to be in front of it.''

headline.main: Hills Defends White House Move on Japan Trade

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: In an initial step linking the Soviet Union more closely to the global economy - a goal urged by the Bush Administration - Moscow is expected to be granted observer status this week in the organization that oversees world trade.

headline.main: WORLD TRADE BODY IS EXPECTED TO LET SOVIETS HAVE ROLE

docs.snippet: LEAD: The Soviet Union was accepted today as an observer in the world organization that oversees international trade, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

byline.original: By BURTON BOLLAG, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: When you announce to your loved ones that you are hopping a freighter to South America and will be gone for two months and they bid you fond farewell on the eve of your departure, why are you seen skulking around town a week later? Because just...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: When you announce to your loved ones that you are hopping a freighter to South America and will be gone for two months and they bid you fond farewell on the eve of your departure, why are you seen skulking around town a week later? Because just as time and tide wait for no man, freighters don't depart for a ready woman.

headline.main: RUNNING AWAY TO SEA, THE FREIGHTER WAY

byline.original: By SUSAN TROTT; Susan Trott is the author of ''The Exception,'' forthcoming from Carroll & Graf

docs.snippet: LEAD: THE WHOLE WORLD WAS WATCHING ON JUNE 22, 1986 , when, in Aztec Stadium in Mexico City, during a quarterfinal match in the most recent World Cup soccer tournament, Diego Armando Maradona of Argentina flew into the air and punched the ball into...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: THE WHOLE WORLD WAS WATCHING ON JUNE 22, 1986 , when, in Aztec Stadium in Mexico City, during a quarterfinal match in the most recent World Cup soccer tournament, Diego Armando Maradona of Argentina flew into the air and punched the ball into the goal of England.

byline.original: By George Vecsey; George Vecsey is a sports columnist for The New York Times
